awd_titl_txt: Hazards SEES: Land Management Strategies for Confronting Risks and Consequences of Wildfire
awd_abstract_narration:
A team consisting of natural scientists and social scientists identifies land management strategies that will reduce the risk and the impacts of wildfires. Federal and state agencies apply fuel treatment techniques such as thinning and controlled burns that often generate unintended consequences for humans and ecosystems because neither the agencies nor the research community fully understand the interactions among fire, vegetation, and ecosystem services. Furthermore, agency decision makers may make decisions about fuel treatments on the basis of public attention, economic considerations, and political dynamics. This research combines an analysis of agency decision making with an understanding of the consequences of fuel treatment for fire risk, water provision, wildlife habitat, and carbon storage. In addition, there are a series of meetings with land managers to ensure that the research helps land managers to improve the management of wildfire in the public lands that border urban areas.

This project involves an integrated model of fuel treatment decision making, fire risk, and watershed ecology and hydrology. The model combines empirical analysis of agency decision making with a stochastic model of fire spread and the Region Hydro-Ecologic Simulation System (RHESSys), a spatially distributed mechanistic model of ecosystem growth and hydrology. The research team uses the model to analyze the impact of fuel treatment decisions and prescribes optimal fuel treatment strategies according to criteria that reflect interactions among climate, vegetation, hydrology, and land management actions. The team uses a series of stakeholder meetings to obtain land manager input in the development of these criteria. The project includes testing the integrated model at Critical Zone Observatory sites in New Mexico and the southern Sierra and at a Long-Term Ecological Research site in Santa Barbara. The team uses state-of-the art computing to develop integrated modeling tools, workflows, documentation, and visualization that support the use of the model by a broader research community and its integration into larger scale earth system models. The work directly facilitates sustainability by helping land managers to optimize fuel treatment strategies for their watersheds to reduce the risks, the frequency, the severity, and the costs of wildfires and support other watershed-scale ecosystem services such as water provision, habitat and carbon sequestration.

Overview

SERI-Fire is a collaboration among natural and social scientists to develop management strategies to prepare for and respond to wildfires in a changing climate using data science and advanced computer simulation modeling and visualization. Key products include a state-of-the-science model of interactions among climate, forests, carbon cycling, water, and fire (RHESSys-WMFire-MSR); an empirical model of how forest management decisions are made (Salience Model); and an interactive visualization (Future Mountain) to help audiences better understand how fire-dominated landscapes are changing with climate change and land management. The team made new discoveries about fire, carbon, water, and climate in Western US ecosystems and about how human decisions both respond to and influence fire regimes in ways that can be suboptimal in reducing risk and that create inequality. We published findings in academic journals such as Nature Climate Change, Economic Inquiry, Environmental Research Letters and others, and incorporated results into graduate and undergraduate education, media, and public outreach events. We also made our new tools accessible to other researchers. 

Key Findings 

Even within relatively small watersheds, the relative sensitivity of wildfire to fuel accumulation and climate change varies spatially on the basis of soil moisture (Hanan et al., 2021). 

Recent increases in area burned and severity throughout the western US have been separately attributed to climate change and fuel accumulation after decades of fire suppression. We used a new model to disentangle these effects and discovered that the relative importance of climate versus fuels varied spatially, which informs where fuel treatments are likely to be most effective. 

Short term (next 5 year) and longer term (next decades) impacts of climate change on fire regimes can be remarkably different (Kennedy et al., 2021). Our model shows that current climate projections for a Sierra watershed will lead to increases in fire severity/size for the next 5-10 years. But if the climate continues to warm, drought will slow the accumulation of fuels and may ultimately reduce fires. (Figure 1)  The downside of this long-term reduction is that it translates into declines in productivity, more forest mortality, less carbon sequestration, and overall reduced forest health. 

In Mediterranean ecosystems, thinning or low intensity fire is unlikely to significantly increase water yield, because of compensating increases in transpiration by remaining trees. But it can help to reduce forest water stress.

Our review of  empirical and modeling studies in the Mediterranean show that increases in streamflow following forest density reduction are rare, though many studies show increases in growth in remaining trees (Tague et al., 2019) (Figure 2). Our own modeling studies with RHESSys-MSR found that most water released from thinning is utilized by remaining vegetation (Burke et al., 2020). 

Fuel treatments can reduce fire severity and reduce drought-related forest water stress and mortality but heir effectiveness varies  substantially with space and over time even within the same watershed.

We used RHESSys-WMFire-MSR to show how fuel treatment effects on water, carbon, and fire risk can vary with topography, climate, fuel treatment type and density, and vegetation (Burke et al., 2020) (Figure 3). This analysis takes advantage of machine learning of RHESSys-WMFire-MSR output to quantify variation in fuel treatment effectiveness for meeting water, carbon, and fire management goals.

Salience

When communities experience nearby wildfire events, it raises the salience of wildfire risk and leads agencies to place a greater number of wildfire risk reduction projects nearby (Wibbenmeyer et al., 2019). 

By analyzing data on when and where fuel treatments are allocated by public agencies within the Western US, we found that fuel treatments are more likely to be placed in areas close to recent fires (Figure 4). This salience effect occurs when management responses are triggered by relatively rare but high severity events. 

Wealthier, whiter, and more educated communities receive more resources after wildfire (Anderson, Plantinga, and Wibbenmeyer, 2020, and under review).

There are environmental justice implications of this salience effect-- communities of color have fewer resources to engage in activities that may increase expenditures on fuel treatments. We found that salience increased rates of fuels treatment near communities with higher percentages of high income, educated, and white residents. These findings reveal ways in which the allocation of government resources may run counter to environmental justice goals, and identify ways in which resource allocation can be modified. 

Science Communication 

Earth system models promote understanding of how landscapes are changing with climate and how human actions, such as fuel treatments, can make a difference. To  help non-experts learn from the rich information embedded in these models, we created Future Mountain: An Interactive Fire, Water, and Climate Model, a game-like video simulation (Figure 5,6). In partnership with a local artist, we included Future Mountain in immersive Walk Into Wildfire art-installations. These exhibits have allowed residents in fire-prone areas to viscerally confront the possibility and ecological presence of fire.
